channel.title: Fork on Uncle Xiang's Notebook
channel.description: Recent content in Fork on Uncle Xiang's Notebook

item.title: Merge Pull Request into forked repository
item.description:
INLINE_CODE_0 is a GitHub profile statistics generator that allows users to display various statistics and charts on their GitHub profiles. It offers multiple customization options to suit user needs.

I manage my warehouse by project groups. GitHub doesn’t support grouped repositories, so I had to use separate organizations. The latest branch couldnâ€™t handle cross-organization repository statistics, so I forked a branch and merged the corresponding code.

Final effect

Original Pull Request Link

Adds the ability to include data from organization repositories

Merge Pull Request into forked repository

There are several ways to merge a [BLANK_0] into your [BLANK_1], depending on what you want to achieve

  1. Merge the PR from ä¸Šæ¸¸ï¼ˆupstreamï¼‰ä»“åº“ into your fork, or
  2. Merge a PR from another person’s fork into your own fork, or
  3. Merge a pull request opened on your fork (e.g., someone created a PR from their fork of yours)

Here’s the translation: Iâ€™ll give you a very common scenario: ä½  fork äº†ä¸€ä¸ªä»“åº“ï¼Œæƒ³æŠŠä¸Šæ¸¸çš„æŸä¸ª PR åˆå¹¶åˆ°ä½ çš„ fork. The operating procedure is as follows ğŸ‘‡:

Method 1: Command-line method (most universal)

Step 1: Clone your own fork 

git clone https://github.com/ä½ çš„ç”¨æˆ·å/ä»“åº“å.git
cd ä»“åº“å

Step 2: Add upstream (original repository address) 

git remote add upstream https://github.com/åŸä½œè€…ç”¨æˆ·å/ä»“åº“å.git

Step 3: Fetch the upstream PR branch

Find the PR number you want to merge, for example, PR #123

You can pull the code for this PR like this:

git fetch upstream pull/123/head:pr-123

Step 4: Switch and merge branches 

git checkout main    # æˆ–è€…ä½ è‡ªå·±çš„ç›®æ ‡åˆ†æ”¯
git merge pr-123

If everything is normal, you can push to your forked GitHub repository

git push origin main

Method Two: GitHub Web Interface (Simple but Limited)

If you see a pull request on GitHub that is against an upstream repository, you can:

  1. Go to that PR page
  2. Click the “Commits” or “Files changed” in the upper right corner to see which branch this PR is based on
  3. On your forked repository, create a new branch and manually cherry-pick the PR’s commits (requires some Git knowledge)
  4. Or click “Open in GitHub Desktop” to merge using a GUI tool

If someone has submitted a pull request for your fork

Simply go to the PR page and click the “Merge pull request” button

Would you like me to walk you through it step-by-step, based on your current situation (e.g., a PR link, whether you’re using the web interface or command line)? Or, you can provide a specific link, and Iâ€™ll help you analyze the simplest approach
